Input.threadtitle: Reorder buffer insertion point in pipeline diagrams
Input.posts:
I spent a ton of time on this tiny detail, so I thought I'll share what I found. \xA0I was trying to figure out the rule to insert something into the reorder buffer. \xA0I think I have it now, but please correct me if I'm wrong. As explained in the lecture, we insert into the ROB from the decode stage. \xA0Fine, sounds good. \xA0But the pipeline diagrams (say L6S4 slide 31, the IIOI processor) showed something different. \xA0Look at cycle 4, as an example. \xA0Instruction 3 is in decode stage, and the top half of the slide agrees. \xA0The lower half does not have the number 3 in the 'D' column, probably for brevity, but the instruction is really there. \xA0So why don't we see instruction 3 appearing in the ROB for the next cycle, cycle 5? \xA0Why did we not insert from the decode stage, as promised? Because that would be incorrect :) \xA0The way I see it now, is that in fact, the decode stage IS sending the insert signals towards the ROB, but since we'll stall the frontend of the pipe, we won't strobe this insert into the ROB. \xA0If we did, then a stalled frontend would enter multiple entries into the ROB. So the precise rule is: We insert into the ROB from the decode step. \xA0However, if we can't issue in this cycle, then (besides skipping the the strobing of the PC and the IR), we also skip the strobing of the ROB insert. \xA0Note however, that we might still strobe an ROB remove, if the commit stage succeeds in committing something, so it's not the whole ROB clock signal that is masked, just the insert selectively.

Looking at Slide 31, even though the Instruction 3 ( MUL R7, R5, R6 ) has been decoded, it cannot Issue as there is a stall underway ( Instruction 2 is waiting on the result of Instruction 0 from the Y3 stage of the pipe ). \xA0 \xA0So an entry is added to the ROB buffer when the Instruction 'transitions from a Decode to Issue stage ( say on rise edge of the clock)'. From a logic point of view, the combinational logic would evaluate the entries to the ROB buffer, but the evaluated entries would not be written due to the Strobe ( perhaps derived from the Stall signal ). \xA0\xA0 \xA0 You also correctly point out that the Decode stage on Cycle 4 is evaluating Instruction 3. \xA0Also that writing to the ROB at the end of the Decode stage would be a mistake because the Instruction has not really been Issued yet - the pipe is stalled.

Yes, you are correct. \xA0Instructions do not enter the ROB until they are issuing from the decode stage. \xA0Stalled instructions in the decode stage do not get entered into the ROB, as you pointed out, because that would result in multiple ROB entries for one instruction.\xA0 Generally, something like an ROB will have an interface with some sort of valid signal that says whether the current request to read/write is valid or not. \xA0You can simply and the valid signal with the inversion of the stall signal. \xA0If the stall signal is 1, the request to write into the ROB is not valid.
